question: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body for 5 days. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a business trip last week in the Bahamas. While he was there, he visited a couple of beaches and went hiking with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23.9 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
prompt:
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body for 5 days. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a business trip last week in the Bahamas. While he was there, he visited a couple of beaches and went hiking with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23.9 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?A)Wood lamp examination
B)Skin culture
C)Potassium hydroxide preparation
D)Skin biopsy
output0: The Wood lamp examination is most likely to confirm the diagnosis of a hypopigmented rash in this patient. The rash has a characteristic appearance under UV light, which is consistent with a diagnosis of a condition such as vitiligo or pityriasis alba. The other options, such as skin culture, potassium hydroxide preparation, and skin biopsy, are not indicated in this case as they are not diagnostic of the condition.
output1: The most likely diagnosis for the patient's hypopigmented rash and pruritus is cutaneous leishmaniasis, which is caused by a parasitic infection. The most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this diagnosis is a skin culture. This test can detect the presence of the parasite in the skin and is more sensitive than other diagnostic tests such as a wood lamp examination or a potassium hydroxide preparation.
output2: A potassium hydroxide preparation is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis of a hypopigmented rash in this patient. The rash has characteristics of vitiligo, a condition that is often associated with autoimmune disorders such as type 1 diabetes mellitus. The potassium hydroxide preparation will help to highlight any areas of depigmentation.
output3: The most likely diagnosis for the patient's hypopigmented rash and pruritus is a fungal infection, such as tinea versicolor. A skin biopsy would be the best way to confirm this diagnosis. A wood lamp examination (A) would not be able to confirm the diagnosis, as it is not a definitive test for fungal infections. Skin culture (B) may be able to identify the presence of fungi, but it would not provide a definitive diagnosis. Potassium hydroxide preparation (C) is not a diagnostic test and would not be useful in this case. A skin biopsy would allow the physician to examine the tissue under a microscope and look for the characteristic signs of a fungal infection, such as hyphae or spores.

question: A 42-year-old male patient was sent to the emergency room for medical treatment, blood pressure was 180/130 mmHg, at 110 beats per minute, a fever, frequent yawning, and complained of diarrhea, abdominal pain, runny nose, watery eyes, muscle ache, bone pain, dilated pupils. This patient most likely clinical diagnosis of why?
prompt:
A 42-year-old male patient was sent to the emergency room for medical treatment, blood pressure was 180/130 mmHg, at 110 beats per minute, a fever, frequent yawning, and complained of diarrhea, abdominal pain, runny nose, watery eyes, muscle ache, bone pain, dilated pupils. This patient most likely clinical diagnosis of why?A)Amphetamine poisoning
B)Amphetamine withdrawal
C)Opiate poisoning
D)Opiate withdrawal
output0: The symptoms described, such as high blood pressure, tachycardia, fever, and dilated pupils, are consistent with amphetamine poisoning. Additionally, the patient's complaints of abdominal pain, muscle ache, and bone pain are also consistent with amphetamine poisoning.
output1: The symptoms described, such as frequent yawning, watery eyes, muscle ache, bone pain, and diarrhea, are consistent with withdrawal symptoms from amphetamines. Additionally, the patient's age and the fact that he was sent to the emergency room for medical treatment suggest that he may have been using amphetamines recreationally.
output2: The symptoms described, such as fever, frequent yawning, diarrhea, abdominal pain, runny nose, watery eyes, and muscle and bone pain, are consistent with opiate withdrawal. Additionally, the patient's age and the presence of a fever suggest that the patient may have been using opiates for a longer period of time.
output3: The symptoms described, such as fever, frequent yawning, diarrhea, abdominal pain, runny nose, watery eyes, muscle ache, and bone pain, are consistent with opiate withdrawal. Additionally, the patient is a 42-year-old male, which is an age group that is more likely to experience opiate addiction.

question: For the diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (Consensus Group, Rotterdam), 2 out of 3 established criteria must be met. What is NOT a diagnostic criterion?
options: D)Polycystic ovaries defined by ultrasound (12 or more follicles per ovary).
prompt:
For the diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (Consensus Group, Rotterdam), 2 out of 3 established criteria must be met. What is NOT a diagnostic criterion?A)Clinical and / or analytical hyperandrogenism.
B)Resistance to insulin.
C)Oligo and / or anovulation.
D)Polycystic ovaries defined by ultrasound (12 or more follicles per ovary).
output0: Clinical and / or analytical hyperandrogenism is not a diagnostic criterion for polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The other three options (resistance to insulin, oligo and / or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries defined by ultrasound) are all diagnostic criteria for PCOS.
output1: Resistance to insulin is not a diagnostic criterion for polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). While insulin resistance is a common feature of PCOS, it is not one of the established diagnostic criteria.
output2: Oligo and / or anovulation are not diagnostic criteria for polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). While oligomenorrhea (infrequent menstrual cycles) and anovulation (the absence of ovulation) are common symptoms of PCOS, they are not required for a diagnosis. The two diagnostic criteria for PCOS are:
output3: The correct answer is D)Polycystic ovaries defined by ultrasound (12 or more follicles per ovary). This is not a diagnostic criterion for polycystic ovarian syndrome (Consensus Group, Rotterdam) because it is not a reliable method for diagnosing the disorder.

question: A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician because she has been feeling pain in her right leg. Specifically, she says that an area on her right thigh has been feeling tender and swollen over the past few weeks. Her past medical history is significant for obesity, poorly controlled diabetes, and hypertension. She also has been taking estrogen replacement therapy and drinking alcohol to cope with her symptoms of menopause. Her family history is significant for cardiomyopathy. On physical exam, there is erythema and edema along a cord-like lesion in her thigh. This lesion feels thick and hardened on palpation and is tender to the touch. She is started on compression therapy as well as NSAIDs for pain management. Which of the following characteristics of this patient most likely increased her risk for this disorder?
prompt:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician because she has been feeling pain in her right leg. Specifically, she says that an area on her right thigh has been feeling tender and swollen over the past few weeks. Her past medical history is significant for obesity, poorly controlled diabetes, and hypertension. She also has been taking estrogen replacement therapy and drinking alcohol to cope with her symptoms of menopause. Her family history is significant for cardiomyopathy. On physical exam, there is erythema and edema along a cord-like lesion in her thigh. This lesion feels thick and hardened on palpation and is tender to the touch. She is started on compression therapy as well as NSAIDs for pain management. Which of the following characteristics of this patient most likely increased her risk for this disorder?A)Alcohol use
B)Diabetes
C)Estrogen therapy
D)Hypertension
output0: The patient's alcohol use is the most likely factor that increased her risk for this disorder. Alcohol consumption can cause vascular damage, which can lead to the development of atherosclerosis and other cardiovascular diseases. Additionally, alcohol can increase blood pressure and worsen diabetes control, both of which are risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The patient's history of poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension also increases her risk for this disorder.
output1: Diabetes is a major risk factor for the development of peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms. The risk of PAD is increased in patients with poorly controlled diabetes, as seen in this patient.
output2: The correct answer is C)Estrogen therapy because estrogen is a known risk factor for the development of thromboembolic disorders, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's history of estrogen replacement therapy and her current use of estrogen likely increased her risk for this disorder.
output3: Hypertension is a significant risk factor for the development of this patient's condition, which is most likely a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Hypertension can cause damage to the blood vessels and increase the risk of blood clots forming. Additionally, the patient's obesity and poorly controlled diabetes may also contribute to her risk of developing DVT.

question: Type II diabetes mellitus:
options: B)It is usually of juvenile appearance.
C)It is not related to obesity.
prompt:
Type II diabetes mellitus:A)It frequently occurs with ketoacidosis.
B)It is usually of juvenile appearance.
C)It is not related to obesity.
D)It is independent insulin.
output0: Type II diabetes mellitus is a condition that is often associated with ketoacidosis. Ketoacidosis is a metabolic state that occurs when the body is unable to produce enough insulin to regulate blood sugar levels, and the body begins to break down fat for energy, producing ketones.
output1: Type II diabetes mellitus is usually associated with a juvenile appearance, meaning that it often develops in children and adolescents. This is in contrast to type I diabetes mellitus, which is typically seen in adults.
output2: Type II diabetes mellitus is not related to obesity, unlike type I diabetes mellitus. Type II diabetes is often associated with insulin resistance, which means that the body's cells do not respond properly to insulin, leading to high blood sugar levels.
output3: Type II diabetes mellitus is a condition in which the body becomes resistant to insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas that regulates blood sugar levels. It is not dependent on insulin, unlike Type I diabetes mellitus, which is an autoimmune disease that destroys the cells in the pancreas that produce insulin.

question: The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for:
prompt:
The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for:A)The European Medicines Agency.
B)World Health Organization.
C)The autonomous communities.
D)UNICEF.
output0: The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for the European Medicines Agency (EMA) because these drugs are designed to treat rare diseases, and the EMA is responsible for evaluating and approving medicines for use in the European Union.
output1: The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO is responsible for the global regulatory framework for orphan drugs, and it provides a centralized process for the authorization of these drugs.
output2: The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for the autonomous communities in Spain, as they have the power to approve and regulate the use of these drugs within their territories. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the World Health Organization (WHO) do not have the authority to approve orphan drugs.
output3: The marketing authorization for orphan drugs is reserved for UNICEF, as these drugs are intended for the treatment of rare diseases that primarily affect children, and UNICEF is the specialized agency of the United Nations that focuses on the health and well-being of children.

question: Commonest variety of compound presentation is ?
prompt:
Commonest variety of compound presentation is ?A)Head with hand
B)Head with foot
C)Head with both foot
D)Head, hand & foot
output0: The most common variety of compound presentation is the head with hand, as it is the most natural and common way for children to present themselves to others. This is especially true for older children, as they are more likely to use this type of presentation in their daily interactions.
output1: The most common variety of compound presentation is the Head with foot, which is often used to help children in this age group develop better self-control and emotional regulation skills.
output2: The most common variety of compound presentation in the turtle technique is head with both feet, as this allows the child to fully relax and feel safe.
output3: The head, hand, and foot are the three most common body parts used in the Turtle Technique. By presenting the child with all three parts, the technique can be used to help them develop better self-control and emotional regulation skills in a more holistic way.

question: About artificial reproductive technology (assisted reproductive technology) of the narrative, Which statement is correct?
correct_answer: The so-called artificial reproductive technology refers to the process of oocyte retrieval through the relevant treatment
options: A)Is the number of embryos increases pregnancy rates, implantation, the better
B)The so-called artificial reproductive technology refers to the process of oocyte retrieval through the relevant treatment
C)Prevention FSH surge artificial reproductive technology is a very important part
D)Induction of ovulation, GnRH-antagonist inhibit FSH surge
prompt:
About artificial reproductive technology (assisted reproductive technology) of the narrative, Which statement is correct?A)Is the number of embryos increases pregnancy rates, implantation, the better
B)The so-called artificial reproductive technology refers to the process of oocyte retrieval through the relevant treatment
C)Prevention FSH surge artificial reproductive technology is a very important part
D)Induction of ovulation, GnRH-antagonist inhibit FSH surge
output0: The correct answer is A)Is the number of embryos increases pregnancy rates, implantation, the better. This is because the transfer of multiple embryos increases the chances of a successful pregnancy and implantation.
output1: The correct answer is B)The so-called artificial reproductive technology refers to the process of oocyte retrieval through the relevant treatment. This is because the term "artificial reproductive technology" refers specifically to the process of retrieving oocytes (eggs) from the body for the purpose of fertility treatment, rather than to the entire process of fertility treatment.
output2: The correct answer is C)Prevention FSH surge artificial reproductive technology is a very important part. This is because the prevention of FSH surge is a critical aspect of assisted reproductive technology. By preventing the surge of FSH, the chances of multiple pregnancies are reduced, which can improve the success rates of the treatment.
output3: The correct answer is D)Induction of ovulation, GnRH-antagonist inhibit FSH surge. This is because GnRH-antagonists are used to prevent the surge of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) that occurs during ovulation, which can improve the success rate of assisted reproductive technology (ART) procedures such as in vitro fertilization (IVF).

question: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a two-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
prompt:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a two-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?A)Stokes-Adams attack
B)Constricted aortic valve orifice
C)Cardiac tumor
D)Left ventricular dilation
output0: The most likely cause of this patient's presentation is a Stokes-Adams attack, which is a transient loss of consciousness due to a brief episode of bilateral ventricular tachycardia. This condition is often caused by a prolonged QT interval, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including smoking, alcohol consumption, and medications such as dutasteride and tamsulosin. The patient's history of dizziness upon standing and the conjunctival pallor on examination are also consistent with this diagnosis.
output1: The patient's history of smoking for 55 years and the presence of a constricted aortic valve orifice suggest that the most likely cause of his presentation is atherosclerosis of the aortic valve. The plopping sound and low-pitched, rumbling murmur heard best at the apex are consistent with this diagnosis.
output2: The patient's history of dizziness upon standing, conjunctival pallor, and the presence of a plopping sound and mid-diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation suggest the possibility of a cardiac tumor. The patient's long history of smoking and alcohol consumption also increase the likelihood of a cardiac tumor. The other options are not likely causes of the patient's presentation.
output3: The patient's presentation of dizziness upon standing, conjunctival pallor, and a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur are all consistent with a left ventricular dilation. The patient's history of smoking and alcohol consumption, as well as his current medications, also support this diagnosis. A Stokes-Adams attack, constricted aortic valve orifice, and cardiac tumor are all less likely causes of this patient's presentation.

question: Descriptive epidemiology includes all Except:
prompt:
Descriptive epidemiology includes all Except:A)Retrospective and prospective study
B)Disease
C)Time
D)Place
output0: Descriptive epidemiology includes all except retrospective and prospective studies. Retrospective studies involve analyzing data that has already been collected, while prospective studies involve collecting data over time.
output1: Descriptive epidemiology is concerned with the description of the distribution of health-related events in a population. It does not include the study of diseases, which is the focus of clinical epidemiology.
output2: Descriptive epidemiology is concerned with the description of the distribution and determinants of health-related events in a population. It does not involve the study of time, which is a key component of analytical epidemiology.
output3: Descriptive epidemiology is concerned with describing the distribution and determinants of health-related events, diseases, or health-related characteristics in a population. It includes studies of retrospective and prospective design, disease, time, and place. Therefore, place is not a key component of descriptive epidemiology.
